reviewText: I found Anthony Hopkins interpretation and the directing quite compelling. Also, nice production values. However, I found the wrting wanting. We learn very little of the inner life of Paul, of his relationship with Jesus, and of his compelling need to spread the "good news" everywhere. It's all very external--he does this and he does that. But the spiritual force and the realizations that drive him are omitted. Also, his transformation from Christian hater to Christian lover is too abrupt. I wanted to to see a believable gradual transformation that is deeply rooted in love for God--from doubt to uncertainty to understanding to belief to conviction to faith to self-sacrifice and final martydom. The character of Peter is one note--self-guilt, self-dissatisfaction, and self-abasement. I wanted to see a more well-rounded Peter--with some indications of hope, strength, love, and even joy (from just his rememberances of his days with Jesus).
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a pretty good movie overall in that the acting is very well done as it should be since some top notch actors and actresses participated in the project done in the early 1980s.  The story lines stay true to the bible as we know it all the while bringing to life the human beings involved in starting Christianity.  Saying this is the best movie on the New Testament after Jesus isn't really saying much at least for me because I don't know of any others but this is a good one that stands alone on its own merits.  But there are two major discrepancies.  One is the portrayal of Peter as not doing all that much in the beginning which may have been true to some degree.  But Peter was actually first to be directed to go to the Gentiles (Cornelius having seen a vision from a rooftop and ministering to them ref Acts 10).  The other is the true power of God which seemed to be downplayed or explainable in what little it was shown.  Supernatural healings and miracles in the ministries of both Peter and Paul were not shown at all.  It is great at being historically accurate and giving reasonable human qualities to major biblical figures but fails in showing the works of God involved in the early church and might I add still works today.

reviewText: Even after watching this movie again and again, it remains my absolute favorite by far!  The acting is realistic--unlike many of the Biblical movies where the acting is so poor I can't watch it!  I can find no fault with this one!  God has used this to inspire me in abundant ways:  Peter and Paul's relationship demonstrates the opposing positions of the Old Covenant of the Law vs. the New Covenant of Grace--even Peter's wavering whether or not anything else is required to be saved--but FAITH!  And that by Grace!  Opposition to the Covenant of Grace is well revealed; every person well portrays the struggles involved with changing from the old to the new.  Paul seems radical to them--as did Jesus!  I am finding it challenging to try to describe the fine production of this movie--but I would certainly recommend this to every single person who is interested in Jesus Christ--without works, without self-effort of any kind, but to see the King of Glory longing for you with open arms!
summary: BEST BIBLE MOVIE I HAVE SEEN--and I have seen most of them produced!

reviewText: It seems to me that this movie was an attempt to be as historically accurate as possible while yet negating the power of God which lies at the true heart of the gospel and the book of Acts.Certain elements of this movie were very accurate as facts of what we know historically, yet the entire spirit of what Luke, the biblical writer of the book of Acts, wrote was lost.  The Baptism of the Holy Spirit is completely omitted along with stories from the lives of these two apostles where the Baptism is revealed or spoken of.  This was no surprise as those portaying the two great apostles are not saved; however, as the baptism in the Holy Spirit was an intregal part of their story - indeed it is the leading arguement for evangelizing the lost gentiles within the book of Acts.  Peter's trance and vision of the sheet let down, followed by His being led of the Spirit into the home of gentiles where a great number of them were baptised in the Holy Spirit ((Acts 10:9-48)and this story is entirely ommited from the movie) was, according to St. Luke's 'Acts' a leading point of discussion at the council in Jerusalem (Acts 15:7&8).There was, further, a complete lack of the miraculous, or anything else that gave credence to the gospel in those early days of the church (yet the power of God wrought toward the gentiles was another leading point in the Jerusalem council (Acts 15:12)).  I counted one miracle done by Paul, which was only worked into the film because it was an absoolutely necesarry plot point, yet, again according to Acts both Paul and Peter were so anointed of the Holy Spirit that scores of miracles were wrought by them constantly (Acts 5:12,15&16; Acts 19:11&12).The portrayal of the early church as a whole was clearly a secular view: the early church fathers were portrayed as cowering zealots attempting to start a religious 'movement' by human power, rather than the faith pioneers revealed in the book of Acts.If you are content with a powerless gospel, built on fleshly human attempts at godliness rather than a relationship with the living God, you may be satisfied with this movie.  I was not.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Robert Foxworth as Saint Peter and Anthony Hopkins as St. Paul are interestingly cast as the title characters.  The film is very good but it is the actors' work that distinguishes the miniseries.  Foxworth seems slightly uncomfortable playing the initially weak man but later finds his faith and strength through Saint Paul.  Foxworth grows into the role through the film's run. Hopkins' portrayal of Saint Paul dominates the mini-series because he brings forth the passion that this once-enemy of Jesus had.  He also successfully brings us through the epiphany of Saint Paul and brings life to the saint.  Overall, the film is faithful to the scriptures and brings in many colorful and essential characters who flesh out the two men's lives and miniseries.  The film was a mini-series so it does run long but it needs to in order to convey the full story.

reviewText: This was really a very strange and not very entertaining movie. If you're interested in seeing Biblical characters brought to life on screen, I would suggest "Quo Vadis" or "Passion of the Christ" perhaps. This movie twists Scripture to create a rivalry and hostility between Peter and Paul that didn't exist. Until the final scenes, it portrays Peter as a mopish, do-nothing, cowardly dunderhead who is constantly bemoaning how worthless he is in comparison to Paul. This is the Peter who was the leader of the Apostles, who boldly preached to Jerusalem on Pentecost, whose very shadow was reputed to heal the sick, the Peter through whose mouth "the Gentiles would hear the word of the gospel"? (Acts 15:7) This would be like a movie portraying Napoleon as an unassuming little milquetoast. Strange. Almost as weird as that was the bizarre histrionics and speech patterns Anthony Hopkins chose to attribute to Paul. When he had to act angry, Hopkins did an exact impression of the role he played as Adolf Hitler in 1980's "The Bunker", ranting and raving apoplectically like the Fuhrer in his last days. (I was always expecting him to start screaming about the Russians). When conversing normally, he spoke in a very disconcerting, clipped manner reminiscent of a bad William Shatner impersonator. To add to the hilarity, the director cast Eddie Arnold (Green Acres) as the Roman Procurator of Judea, who sleepwalked through his performance in his out-of-place Midwestern accent. All in all, a pretty bad movie.

reviewText: While films based on the Bible seem to use a great deal of poetic license (Some much more so than others.), "Peter and Paul" seems comparatively faithful - at least with regard to Paul - and superior to that better known film about the early Church, "A.D."  HOWEVER, it is highly inadequate in its treatment of Peter.  It should probably be packaged as "peter and !!!PAUL!!!."  Saint Peter, to whom Christ gave the keys of the Kingdom, is treated as as afterthought!
summary: More Paul than Peter, BUT Better Film about the Early Church, than "A.D."  Yet, Peter is treated as an afterthought.

reviewText: First, I agree with other reviewers here that the portrayal of Paul the Apostle by Anthony Hopkins is a standout performance worthy of an emmy nomination. Robert Foxworth's Peter is also interestingly done but our information is lacking about his ministry when he disappears after Chapter 7 in the book of Acts. Therefore the movie focuses on Paul's attempt to unite Jew,Greek and Roman in a trinity of new Christian faith and this film delivers on that concept, even though it is somewhat romanticized. Some very effective scenes remind you of "Jesus of Nazareth". One suprise is when Paul is being confronted by his "thorn in the flesh" while consulting with Barnabas and Mark, you hear a mysterious sound that is tough to catch but Mark inquires what it is to which Paul replies "just an animal". (Actually it is a devil). Also there is a great confrontation with the woman who throws her voice into statues and animals to ridicule Paul's ministry. When Paul tells her that she won't have the power to do that again it is effective enough to put a fear of the Lord into you! We get to see the journeys of Paul and Barnabas (you will notice a gradual decline in the richness of Barnabas shown in his clothing) , we meet Luke, Timothy, Silas, Mark and get a basic grip on what the spread of Christianity was all about in the ancient world. Nero's fay behavior will get on your nerves especially when he is engaged in conversations about Paul with his jailer. Paul's triumphant entry as a prisoner into Rome will remind you of Jesus and his entry into Jerusalem so much so that it can bring a tear to your eye. The original scene of Paul forgiving the Axeman when he is beheaded has been removed for some reason on this DVD. Well recommended to anyone who wants some insight into the early development of the Church and to understand persecution of the apostles!
summary: The Book of Acts made interesting and understandable!

reviewText: I bought this video because I'd just taught the Book of Acts to my teen Sunday School.  There are few videos related to Acts so I tried this out as I liked the casting.The first half is too slow, too dry for my taste.  The initial depiction of Saul hesitant to stone a Christian was inaccurate--in fact he couldn't wait to kill Christians!  In the New Testament he's like a Gestapo enjoying his hunt for Jews.  Through the middle I couldn't stand it--just too boring. So, I nearly turned it off.  Instead I forwarded to the last quarter.  The latter part, beginning with the shipwreck off Malta is better paced, acted, and watchable. It gives a better ending to the Book of Acts than the Book, closing with the deaths of Paul and Peter.  Nero is interesting too.  Because of the last segment of the movie, which lasts about 40 minutes, I'd say watch that part.

reviewText: First the Bad - The portrayal of Peter is extremely wimpy. A far better portrayal can be found in A.D. played by Denis Quilley.Now the Good - The portrayal of Paul by Anthony Hopkins was fantastic. The emotion and passion he put into his preaching before the Greeks was excellent. He also portrayed well the human side of Paul. The character of Nero, expertly portrayed by Julian Fellowes, was alone worth the purchase of the DVD. I can only describe it as total creepiness under control.
